Question: Can someone post a program template for submitting a solution in Java in Codeforces programming competitions?: :Yes I want to start programming competitions so I dont know how to submit in Java?Answers very apreciatedbye
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION

API: StringTokenizer
Code:
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer("Hello World");
        while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
            System.out.println(st.nextToken());
        }
    }
}

Explanation: In this code, we are using the StringTokenizer class to split the string "Hello World" into tokens. The tokens are the words "Hello" and "World". We then print each token using a while loop and the nextToken() method.

Note: The StringTokenizer class is a legacy class that is recommended to be used only for its simplicity and lack of support for Unicode. For more complex string tokenization tasks, consider using the java.util.Scanner class or the java.util.regex.Pattern class.

This code will work in Codeforces, but please note that Codeforces does not support the StringTokenizer class. Instead, it uses the java.util.Scanner class for input. If you are preparing for a Codeforces competition, you should use the java.util.Scanner class instead.

Here is the updated code:

```java
import java.util.Scanner;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
        while (scanner.hasNext()) {
            System.out.println(scanner.next());
        }
    }
}
```

This code will read the input from the standard input (usually the keyboard) and print each token on a new line. It will continue to do this until the user enters an end-of-file (Ctrl+Z on Windows, Ctrl+D on Unix/Linux, or Ctrl+C on Mac).
